name: GitHub Copilot
description: GitHub Copilot is an AI pair programmer that suggests code as you type. It's incredibly powerful—but also dangerous for beginners who accept suggestions without understanding them. This topic teaches you to use Copilot as a productivity multiplier while maintaining code ownership.
note: We focus on GitHub Copilot because it's one of the most popular AI coding assistants, but feel free to use other tools like Cursor, Codeium, or Amazon CodeWhisperer. The techniques you learn here—understanding before accepting, using AI for review rather than generation, maintaining code ownership—apply to all AI coding tools.

learning_steps.title: GitHub Copilot Quickstart
learning_steps.description: Complete the official GitHub Copilot quickstart to get familiar with basic features and your first AI-assisted coding session.

Before accepting ANY Copilot suggestion, ask yourself:

• Can I explain what this code does line by line?
• Would I have written something similar myself?
• Does this match what I intended, or is Copilot guessing?
• Are there edge cases this doesn't handle?

If you can't answer YES to these, REJECT the suggestion and write it yourself.

Copilot Chat is great for:

• Explaining code: Select code, ask "Explain this"
• Reviewing code: "What could be improved here?"
• Understanding errors: "Why am I getting this error?"
• Learning patterns: "What's a better way to do this?"

It's NOT great for:
• Writing entire features from scratch
• Fixing bugs without understanding them
• Generating code you won't read

Open your Journal API from Phase 2. Add a new feature (e.g., a search endpoint). As Copilot makes suggestions:

1. Before accepting, write a comment explaining what the suggestion does
2. Only accept if your comment is accurate
3. If you're wrong, reject and research why

This builds the habit of understanding before accepting.

Select different parts of your Phase 2 code and ask Copilot Chat:

• "How would you improve this function?"
• "What edge cases am I missing?"
• "Is there a more Pythonic way to write this?"

Then implement the improvements yourself. Don't let Copilot rewrite it for you.

questions.prompt: When should you reject a GitHub Copilot suggestion even if it appears to be correct code?
scenario_seeds: Copilot suggests a complete authentication function that looks professional but uses patterns you've never seen before
You're writing a database query and Copilot autocompletes with what appears to be working SQL
A junior developer on your team accepts every Copilot suggestion because 'the code runs without errors'
questions.grading_rubric: Must explain the core principle (reject if you can't explain it line by line) AND identify specific warning signs (unfamiliar patterns, can't verify edge cases) AND articulate why code ownership matters for learning.

questions.prompt: Walk me through the effective and ineffective uses of GitHub Copilot Chat for development.
scenario_seeds: You're stuck on a bug and considering whether to paste your code into Copilot Chat with 'fix this'
A teammate uses Copilot Chat to generate entire features from scratch without writing any code themselves
You want to understand why your async code isn't working as expected
questions.grading_rubric: Must identify effective uses (explaining code, reviewing for improvements, understanding errors) AND ineffective uses (writing entire features, fixing without understanding) AND explain WHY each category matters.

bonus: using Chat to learn patterns vs bypass learning
Chat as teaching assistant not ghostwriter

test_knowledge_prompts: Can you quiz me on when to accept vs. reject Copilot suggestions?
Can you ask me to demonstrate the explain-before-accept technique?
Can you challenge me on good vs. bad uses of AI code assistants?
